Description: Rim sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery light chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; part of palmette and lotus flower in added red and white; exterior: reversed z frieze between pairs of narrow bands; below, painted decoration consisting of muzzled horse (only muzzle remaining) to right; large rosette as filling ornament to right.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group with the Filling Ornament. The features typical for this group of vessels are the milky white slip and the use of filling ornament, which is found only in this group of sherds of the Grand Style. The presence of filling ornament also suggests that the vases were mostly likely the earliest in that style. The male figures portrayed on vases from this group are perhaps the most expertly depicted and may all have been done by the same hand.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 33, no. 15, pl. XVII, no. 15, no. 48)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 110, p. 280, no. 774, pl. 101)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0818) (phase 2)
